two touchdowns in a 38–24 win to advance to [[Super Bowl LV]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=AFC Championship – Buffalo Bills at Kansas City Chiefs – January 24th, 2021 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202101240kan.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210130150035/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202101240kan.htm |archive-date=January 30, 2021 |access-date=January 31, 2021 |website=[[Pro Football Reference]] |language=en}}</ref> In the Super Bowl, he caught 10 passes for 133 yards—a record for receiving yards by a tight end in the championship game—but the Chiefs did not score a touchdown in the 31–9 loss to the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Junda |first=Zach |date=February 8, 2021 |title=White, Fournette Help Lead Bucs to Super Bowl 55 Win |url=https://www.andthevalleyshook.com/2021/2/8/22272150/white-fournette-help-lead-bucs-to-super-bowl-55-win |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210208141725/https://www.andthevalleyshook.com/2021/2/8/22272150/white-fournette-help-lead-bucs-to-super-bowl-55-win |archive-date=February 8, 2021 |access-date=February 8, 2021 |website=And The Valley Shook |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=February 8, 2021 |title=Travis Kelce: 133 receiving yards in the Chiefs' 31–9 loss vs. Tampa Bay. Most ever by a TE in a Super Bowl |url=https://twitter.com/pff/status/1358845834394284033 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210208183212/https://twitter.com/PFF/status/1358845834394284033 |archive-date=February 8, 2021 |access-date=March 4, 2021 |website=Twitter |publisher=PFF |language=en}}</ref> He was ranked fifth by his fellow players on the [[NFL Top 100 Players of 2021]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=2021 NFL Top 100 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/awards/2021-nfl-top-100.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211115200023/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/awards/2021-nfl-top-100.htm |archive-date=November 15, 2021 |access-date=September 2, 2022 |website=[[Pro Football Reference]] |language=en}}</ref>

===2021 season===
[[File:Cole Holcomb chasing Travis Kelce OCT2021 (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|upright=1|Kelce playing against the [[Washington Football Team]] in 2021]]
{{See also|2021 Kansas City Chiefs season}}
After Fisher was released and Sherman retired in the offseason, Kelce became the longest-tenured member of the Chiefs.<ref name=":0"/> In the Chiefs' second game of the season, against the Ravens, he became the fastest tight end in NFL history to record 8,000 career yards, surpassing [[Rob Gronkowski]]'s record in 113 games.<ref name="8000 yards">{{Cite web |last=Palmer |first=Tod |date=September 20, 2021 |title=Chiefs TE Travis Kelce continues to build Hall of Fame résumé against Ravens |url=https://www.kshb.com/sports/kelce-continues-to-build-hall-of-fame-resume-against-ravens |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211017004030/https://www.kshb.com/sports/kelce-continues-to-build-hall-of-fame-resume-against-ravens |archive-date=October 17, 2021 |access-date=February 3, 2022 |website=KSHB |language=en}}</ref> In the Chiefs' week-15 game against the Chargers, Kelce set a career high for receiving yards in a game with 191 yards. He also caught two touchdowns, including the game-winning 34-yard touchdown in overtime.<ref>{{Cite web |date=December 17, 2021 |title=Kelce's OT touchdown gives Chiefs 34–28 win over Chargers |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/game/_/gameId/401326537 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220201045322/https://www.espn.com/nfl/game/_/gameId/401326537 |archive-date=February 1, 2022 |access-date=February 2, 2022 |website=[[ESPN.com]] |agency=[[Associated Press]]}}</ref> Kelce was named AFC Offensive Player of the Week for his performance.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Gordon |first=Grant |date=December 22, 2021 |title=Packers QB Aaron Rodgers, Chiefs TE Travis Kelce lead Players of the Week |url=https://www.nfl.com/news/players-of-the-week-2021-week-15-aaron-rodgers-travis-kelce |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220113012121/https://www.nfl.com/news/players-of-the-week-2021-week-15-aaron-rodgers-travis-kelce |archive-date=January 13, 2022 |access-date=February 2, 2022 |website=[[NFL.com]]}}</ref> The game also put him over 1,000 yards for the season, his NFL record (among tight ends) extending sixth consecutive 1,000-yard season. It also extended Kelce's record for most 1,000-yard seasons by a tight end with six. He was placed on the Reserve/COVID-19 list on December 20, 2021.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Brisco |first=Joshua |date=December 20, 2021 |title=Travis Kelce, Charvarius Ward, Harrison Butker Placed on Reserve/COVID-19 List |url=https://www.si.com/nfl/chiefs/news/kc-chiefs-te-travis-kelce-placed-on-reserve-covid-19-list |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211229200556/https://www.si.com/nfl/chiefs/news/kc-chiefs-te-travis-kelce-placed-on-reserve-covid-19-list |archive-date=December 29, 2021 |access-date=February 3, 2022 |magazine=[[Sports Illustrated]] Kansas City Chiefs News, Analysis and More |language=en}}</ref> Kelce was activated on December 25, 2021.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Teicher |first=Adam |date=December 25, 2021 |title=Receiver Tyreek Hill, activated by Kansas City Chiefs, will play Week 16 against Pittsburgh Steelers |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/32936512/receiver-tyreek-hill-activated-kansas-city-chiefs-play-week-16-pittsburgh-steelers |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220125041054/https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/32936512/receiver-tyreek-hill-activated-kansas-city-chiefs-play-week-16-pittsburgh-steelers |archive-date=January 25, 2022 |access-date=February 2, 2022 |website=[[ESPN.com]]}}</ref> However, due to NFL protocols for [[COVID-19]], since he tested positive for the virus and did not test negative before the day of the game, he was ruled out for the Chiefs' week 16 game against the Steelers. It was the first game Kelce had missed due to injury or illness since his rookie season.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Teicher |first=Adam |date=December 26, 2021 |title=Kansas City Chiefs TE Travis Kelce still in COVID-19 protocol; out vs. Pittsburgh Steelers |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/32939954/source-kansas-city-chiefs-te-travis-kelce-covid-19-protocol-vs-pittsburgh-steelers |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220125035751/https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/32939954/source-kansas-city-chiefs-te-travis-kelce-covid-19-protocol-vs-pittsburgh-steelers |archive-date=January 25, 2022 |access-date=February 2, 2022 |website=[[ESPN.com]]}}</ref> In the regular season-ending game against the Broncos, Kelce became the fastest tight end in NFL history to reach 9,000 career yards in just 127 games, a record also previously held by Gronkowski with 140 games.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Goldman |first=Charles |date=January 9, 2022 |title=Chiefs TE Travis Kelce quickest at his position to 9,000 career receiving yards |url=https://chiefswire.usatoday.com/2022/01/08/kansas-city-chiefs-travis-kelce-fastest-tight-end-to-9000-career-receiving-yards/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220109233752/https://chiefswire.usatoday.com/2022/01/08/kansas-city-chiefs-travis-kelce-fastest-tight-end-to-9000-career-receiving-yards/ |archive-date=January 9, 2022 |access-date=February 3, 2022 |website=Chiefs Wire |language=en-US}}</ref> He finished the season with 92 receptions for 1,125 receiving yards and nine touchdowns. He was named Second-Team All-Pro by the AP, his sixth overall All-Pro selection. He was also named to his seventh consecutive Pro Bowl.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Goldman |first=Charles |date=December 20, 2021 |title=Chiefs TE Travis Kelce selected for 7th consecutive Pro Bowl |url=https://chiefswire.usatoday.com/2021/12/20/kansas-city-chiefs-travis-kelce-2022-pro-bowl-selection-seventh-consecutive-streak/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220203012255/https://chiefswire.usatoday.com/2021/12/20/kansas-city-chiefs-travis-kelce-2022-pro-bowl-selection-seventh-consecutive-streak/ |archive-date=February 3, 2022 |access-date=February 3, 2022 |website=Chiefs Wire |language=en-US}}</ref>

In the [[2021–22 NFL playoffs#AFC: Kansas City Chiefs 42, Pittsburgh Steelers 21|Wild Card Round]] against the Pittsburgh Steelers, Kelce had five receptions for 108 yards and a receiving touchdown to go along with a two-yard touchdown pass to [[Byron Pringle]] in the 42–21 victory.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Wild Card – Pittsburgh Steelers at Kansas City Chiefs – January 16th, 2022 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202201160kan.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220128104256/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202201160kan.htm |archive-date=January 28, 2022 |access-date=February 3, 2022 |website=[[Pro Football Reference]] |language=en}}</ref> In the [[2021 AFC Divisional playoff game (Buffalo–Kansas City)|Divisional Round]] against the Bills, he had eight receptions for 96 yards and the game-winning touchdown in the 42–36 overtime victory.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Divisional Round – Buffalo Bills at Kansas City Chiefs – January 23rd, 2022 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202201230kan.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220130192305/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202201230kan.htm |archive-date=January 30, 2022 |access-date=February 3, 2022 |website=[[Pro Football Reference]] |language=en}}</ref> Kelce was wearing an [[NFL Films]] microphone for the game, and audio footage from the two offensive plays of the 13-second drive revealed that Kelce instructed [[Tyreek Hill]] to run the route which led to the success of the first completion, and revealed him suggesting to Mahomes that he might improvise his own route on the second offensive play if the Bills' defensive scheme didn't change. Prior to the snap, Mahomes realized Kelce's suggested improvised route would work and shouted "Do it, Kelce!", before finding his tight-end for a completion of 25 yards.<ref>{{cite web |last=Smith |first=Michael David |title=Travis Kelce was mic'd up, told teammates which routes would be open on game-tying drive |url=https://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2022/01/26/travis-kelce-was-micd-up-told-teammates-which-routes-would-be-open-on-game-tying-drive/ |website=NBCsports.com |date=January 26, 2022 |access-date=January 26, 2022 |archive-date=April 6, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230406093103/https://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2022/01/26/travis-kelce-was-micd-up-told-teammates-which-routes-would-be-open-on-game-tying-drive/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

In the [[2021–22 NFL playoffs#AFC: Cincinnati Bengals 27, Kansas City Chiefs 24 (OT)|AFC Championship]] against the [[Cincinnati Bengals]], he had 10 receptions for 95 yards and a touchdown in the 27–24 overtime loss.<ref>{{Cite web |title=AFC Championship – Cincinnati Bengals at Kansas City Chiefs – January 30th, 2022 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202201300kan.htm |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220201165424/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202201300kan.htm |archive-date=February 1, 2022 |access-date=February 3, 2022 |website=[[Pro Football Reference]] |language=en}}</ref> He was ranked tenth by his fellow players on the [[NFL Top 100 Players of 2022]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=2022 NFL Top 100 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/awards/2022-nfl-top-100.htm |access-date=January 25, 2024 |website=[[Pro Football Reference]] |language=en |archive-date=December 13, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221213101426/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/awards/2022-nfl-top-100.htm |url-status=live }}</ref>

===2022 season: Second Super Bowl win===
[[File:President Joe Biden greets Kansas City Chiefs' President Mark Donovan, Head Coach Andy Reid and players Patrick Mahomes and Travis Kelce in the Oval Office of the White House on June 5, 2023 - P20230605AS-0902.jpg|thumb|Kelce (left) with President [[Joe Biden]] in 2023]]
{{See also|2022 Kansas City Chiefs season}}
In Week 5, Kelce had four receiving touchdowns in the 30–29 victory over the Raiders.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Las Vegas Raiders at Kansas City Chiefs – October 10th, 2022 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202210100kan.htm |access-date=October 11, 2022 |website=[[Pro Football Reference]] |language=en |archive-date=October 11, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221011142747/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202210100kan.htm |url-status=live }}</ref> Kelce tied the franchise record for receiving touchdowns in a game.<ref name="FourTDs">{{Cite web |last=Grathoff |first=Pete |date=October 10, 2022 |title=KC Chiefs' Travis Kelce set a quirky NFL record with his four touchdown receptions |url=https://www.kansascity.com/sports/spt-columns-blogs/for-petes-sake/article267135586.html |access-date=October 11, 2022 |website=The Kansas City Star}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=White |first=Peter |date=February 17, 2023 |title='SNL': Travis Kelce & Jenna Ortega Among Hosts For Three Back-To-Back Shows |url=https://deadline.com/2023/02/snl-travis-kelce-jenna-ortega-to-host-1235262841/ |access-date=February 17, 2023 |website=Deadline |language=en-US |archive-date=February 17, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230217024452/https://deadline.com/2023/02/snl-travis-kelce-jenna-ortega-to-host-1235262841/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In the Chiefs' Week 11 game against the Chargers, he recorded his NFL record-breaking (among tight ends) 33rd 100-yard receiving game with 115 yards. He also scored three touchdowns, including the game-winning touchdown, his second straight season recording a game-winning touchdown against the Chargers.<ref name="Hundred yard games"/> In Week 14 against the Broncos, he became the fifth tight end in NFL history to have 10,000 receiving yards. He also officially recorded his seventh consecutive 1,000-yard season, extending his records (among tight ends) of consecutive 1,000-yard seasons and most overall 1,000 seasons.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Teope |first=Herbie |date=December 12, 2022 |title=Chiefs' Travis Kelce achieves 2 notable career milestones on same play vs. Broncos |url=https://www.kansascity.com/sports/nfl/kansas-city-chiefs/article269880677.html |access-date=December 13, 2022 |website=KansasCity.com |archive-date=December 18, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221218231906/https://www.kansascity.com/sports/nfl/kansas-city-chiefs/article269880677.html |url-status=live }}</ref> He finished the 2022 season with 110 receptions for 1,338 receiving yards and 12 receiving touchdowns.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Travis Kelce 2022 Game Log |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/K/KelcTr00/gamelog/2022/ |access-date=February 20, 2023 |website=[[Pro Football Reference]] |language=en |archive-date=February 20, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230220155820/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/K/KelcTr00/gamelog/2022/ |url-status=live }}</ref>
Kelce set a single-game NFL postseason record for a tight end with 14 receptions in a 27–20 victory over the Jaguars in the [[2022–23 NFL playoffs#AFC: Kansas City Chiefs 27, Jacksonville Jaguars 20|Divisional Round]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=DeArdo |first=Bryan |date=January 21, 2023 |title=2023 NFL playoffs: Chiefs' Travis Kelce breaks own postseason record in divisional round win vs. Jaguars |url=https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/2023-nfl-playoffs-chiefs-travis-kelce-breaks-own-postseason-record-in-divisional-round-win-vs-jaguars/ |access-date=February 20, 2023 |website=CBSSports.com |language=en |archive-date=February 20, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230220160124/https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/2023-nfl-playoffs-chiefs-travis-kelce-breaks-own-postseason-record-in-divisional-round-win-vs-jaguars/ |url-status=live }}</ref> He scored two receiving touchdowns in the game.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Divisional Round - Jacksonville Jaguars at Kansas City Chiefs - January 21st, 2023 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202301210kan.htm |access-date=February 20, 2023 |website=[[Pro Football Reference]] |language=en |archive-date=February 9, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230209180644/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202301210kan.htm |url-status=live }}</ref> Kelce and the Chiefs appeared in [[Super Bowl LVII]] against the Eagles. Kelce's brother Jason played for the Eagles, making it the first Super Bowl to feature two brothers as players on opposing teams.<ref>{{cite web |last=McEvoy |first=Colin |title=The Ultimate Sibling Rivalry: 8 Sets of Brothers Who Faced Off in Sports Championships |work=[[Biography (TV program)|Biography]] |date=February 9, 2023 |url=https://www.biography.com/athletes/a42805051/brothers-who-have-faced-off-in-championships |access-date=February 12, 2023 |archive-date=February 12, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230212152702/https://www.biography.com/athletes/a42805051/brothers-who-have-faced-off-in-championships |url-status=live }}</ref> Kelce caught six passes for 81 yards and a touchdown as the Chiefs beat the Eagles 38–35 to win his second [[Super Bowl]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Super Bowl LVII - Philadelphia Eagles vs. Kansas City Chiefs - February 12th, 2023 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202302120phi.htm |access-date=February 20, 2023 |website=[[Pro Football Reference]] |language=en |archive-date=February 26, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230226043403/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/202302120phi.htm |url-status=live }}</ref> He was ranked fifth by his fellow players on the [[NFL Top 100 Players of 2023]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=2023 NFL Top 100 |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/awards/2023-nfl-top-100.htm |access-date=January 25, 2024 |website=[[Pro Football Reference]] |language=en |archive-date=August 14, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230814143139/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/awards/2023-nfl-top-100.htm |url-status=live }}</ref>

=== 2023 season: Third Super Bowl win ===
[[File:Travis Kelce KC Chiefs 2023 season.jpg|thumb|Kelce (center) before a 2023 game against the [[Denver Broncos]]]]
{{see also|2023 Kansas City Chiefs season}}
Kelce was inactive for the Chiefs' game against the [[Detroit Lions]] due to a knee injury he suffered earlier in the week. It was his first game missed due to an injury since his rookie season.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Gordon |first=Grant |date=September 7, 2023 |title=Chiefs TE Travis Kelce (knee) out for 2023 NFL Kickoff Game vs. Lions |url=https://www.nfl.com/news/chiefs-te-travis-kelce-knee-will-miss-2023-nfl-kickoff-game-vs-lions |access-date=September 27, 2023 |website=[[NFL.com]] |language=en-US |archive-date=September 27, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230927210151/https://www.nfl.com/news/chiefs-te-travis-kelce-knee-will-miss-2023-nfl-kickoff-game-vs-lions |url-status=live }}</ref> Kelce made his season debut the following week against the Jaguars.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Travis Kelce 2023 Stats per Game - NFL |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/player/gamelog/_/id/15847/travis-kelce |access-date=September 27, 2023 |website=ESPN |language=en |archive-date=September 27, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230927210150/https://www.espn.com/nfl/player/gamelog/_/id/15847/travis-kelce |url-status=live }}</ref> In the Chiefs' week 7 game against the Chargers, Kelce tied a career high with 12 receptions. He also had 179 receiving yards, the second highest of his career.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Teicher |first=Adam |date=October 23, 2023 |title=Another 'monster' game for Kelce as Chiefs cruise |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/38722462/travis-kelce-179-yards-headline-chiefs-win-chargers |access-date=January 25, 2024 |website=[[ESPN.com]] |language=en |archive-date=January 25, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240125145910/https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/38722462/travis-kelce-179-yards-headline-chiefs-win-chargers |url-status=live }}</ref> In the Chiefs' Week 9 game against the Dolphins, he broke the Chiefs franchise record for career receiving yards.<ref name="ChiefsYards">{{Cite web |last=Swartz |first=Gabe |date=November 5, 2023 |title=Kelce sets Chiefs record for receiving yards |url=https://www.kctv5.com/2023/11/05/kelce-sets-franchise-record-receiving-yards/ |access-date=January 25, 2024 |website=KCTV.com |archive-date=November 5, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231105192453/https://www.kctv5.com/2023/11/05/kelce-sets-franchise-record-receiving-yards/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Kelce finished the regular season with 984 receiving yards on 93 receptions and five touchdowns.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Travis Kelce 2023 Game Log |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/K/KelcTr00/gamelog/2023/ |access-date=January 25, 2024 |website=[[Pro Football Reference]] |language=en |archive-date=January 25, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240125161808/https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/K/KelcTr00/gamelog/2023/ |url-status=live }}</ref> He elected to not play in the Chiefs' Week 18 matchup against the [[2023 Los Angeles Chargers season|Los Angeles Chargers]], ending his NFL-record streak of seven consecutive seasons to finish with 1,000 receiving yards.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2024/01/10/chiefs-travis-kelce-opens-up-about-not-playing-in-finale|title=Travis Kelce Opened Up About Why it Didn't 'Feel Right' to Play in Chiefs' Finale Just for Stats|last=Sweeney|first=Kevin|magazine=Sports Illustrated|date=January 10, 2024|access-date=January 10, 2024|language=en|archive-date=January 10, 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240110213307/https://www.si.com/nfl/2024/01/10/chiefs-travis-kelce-opens-up-about-not-playing-in-finale|url-status=live}}</ref>

In the Divisional Round victory over the Bills, Kelce had two receiving touchdowns.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Dillon |first=John |date=January 22, 2024 |title=WATCH: Chiefs QB Patrick Mahomes, Travis Kelce connect for second touchdown vs. Bills |url=https://chiefswire.usatoday.com/2024/01/21/kansas-city-chiefs-patrick-mahomes-travis-kelce-connect-for-second-touchdown-vs-buffalo-bills/ |access-date=January 25, 2024 |website=Chiefs Wire |publisher=USA Today |language=en-US |archive-date=January 31, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240131200349/https://chiefswire.usatoday.com/2024/01/21/kansas-city-chiefs-patrick-mahomes-travis-kelce-connect-for-second-touchdown-vs-buffalo-bills/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Kelce, along with Mahomes, broke the record for most career touchdowns in the playoffs for a quarterback/receiver duo.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Gordon |first=Grant |date=January 21, 2024 |title=Chiefs' Patrick Mahomes, Travis Kelce pass Tom Brady, Rob Gronkowski for most playoff TDs by QB-receiver combo |url=https://www.nfl.com/news/chiefs-patrick-mahomes-travis-kelce-match-tom-brady-rob-gronkowski-for-most-playoff-tds-by-qb-receiver-combo |access-date=January 23, 2024 |website=[[NFL.com]] |archive-date=January 22, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240122210314/https://www.nfl.com/news/chiefs-patrick-mahomes-travis-kelce-match-tom-brady-rob-gronkowski-for-most-playoff-tds-by-qb-receiver-combo |url-status=live }}</ref> In the AFC Championship Game victory against the top-seeded Baltimore Ravens, Kelce caught 11 passes for 116 yards and a touchdown, surpassing [[Jerry Rice]] for most playoff receptions and tying Rice for first in 100+ receiving yard games.<ref name ="AFC CHAMP">{{Cite web |last=Shook |first=Nick |date=January 28, 2024 |title=NFL playoffs: What We Learned from Chiefs' win over Ravens in AFC Championship Game |url=https://www.nfl.com/news/2023-nfl-playoffs-what-we-learned-chiefs-ravens-afc-championship-game |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240128232300/https://www.nfl.com/news/2023-nfl-playoffs-what-we-learned-chiefs-ravens-afc-championship-game |archive-date=January 28, 2024 |access-date=January 28, 2024 |website=[[NFL.com]]}}</ref> The victory marked Kelce's fourth Super Bowl appearance in five seasons.<ref name ="AFC CHAMP"/>

During [[Super Bowl LVIII]], Kelce had nine receptions for 93 yards and was the leading yards receiver for the game. The Chiefs would win 25–22 in just the second Super Bowl in history to go to overtime, earning Kelce his third Super Bowl win.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Maaddi |first=Rob |date=February 12, 2024 |title=Patrick Mahomes rallies the Chiefs to second straight Super Bowl title, 25–22 over 49ers in overtime |url=https://apnews.com/article/super-bowl-2024-score-chiefs-49ers-49b5dca51c05ab0f259cef0d7da76c2d |access-date=February 14, 2024 |website=AP News |language=en |archive-date=February 13, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240213012336/https://apnews.com/article/super-bowl-2024-score-chiefs-49ers-49b5dca51c05ab0f259cef0d7da76c2d |url-status=live }}</ref> The Chiefs became the first team to repeat as Super Bowl champions since the [[2004 New England Patriots season|New England Patriots]] accomplished the feat in the 2003 and 2004 seasons.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=Sullivan |first1=Tyler |last2=Dubin |first2=Jared |date=February 12, 2024 |title=Super Bowl 2024, Chiefs vs. 49ers score: Patrick Mahomes leads OT comeback as K.C. wins back-to-back titles |url=https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/super-bowl-2024-chiefs-vs-49ers-score-patrick-mahomes-leads-ot-comeback-as-k-c-wins-back-to-back-titles/live/ |access-date=February 12, 2024 |website=CBSSports.com |archive-date=February 12, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240212035840/https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/super-bowl-2024-chiefs-vs-49ers-score-patrick-mahomes-leads-ot-comeback-as-k-c-wins-back-to-back-titles/live/ |url-status=live }}</ref> During the game, following a fumble by Chiefs running back [[Isiah Pacheco]] when Kelce was not on the field, he was shown screaming at the Chiefs' head coach [[Andy Reid]]. The incident drew criticism, for which Kelce later apologized through his podcast.<ref>{{cite web |title=Chiefs' Travis Kelce: Bumping, yelling at Andy Reid 'unacceptable' |url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/39524733/chiefs-travis-kelce-bumping-yelling-andy-reid-unacceptable |website=[[ESPN.com]] |date=February 14, 2024 |access-date=February 20, 2024 |archive-date=February 20, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240220001914/https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/39524733/chiefs-travis-kelce-bumping-yelling-andy-reid-unacceptable |url-status=live }}</ref> He was ranked ninth by his fellow players on the [[NFL Top 100 Players of 2024]].<ref name="a407">{{cite web | title=2024 NFL Top 100 | website=Pro-Football-Reference.com | url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/awards/2024-nfl-top-100.htm | access-date=October 24, 2024}}</ref>

=== 2024 season ===
{{see also|2024 Kansas City Chiefs season}}
On April 29, 2024, Kelce signed a two-year extension with the Chiefs for a reported $34.25 million, making him the highest-paid tight end in the NFL.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2024/apr/29/travis-kelce-extension-kansas-city-chiefs-contract |title=Kansas City Chiefs sign Travis Kelce to two-year extension for reported $34m |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=April 29, 2024 |access-date=April 30, 2024 |archive-date=April 30, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240430002138/https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2024/apr/29/travis-kelce-extension-kansas-city-chiefs-contract |url-status=live }}</ref> Kelce started the season slow with just 8 catches for 69 yards in the team's first three games. In Week 4 against the [[Los Angeles Chargers]], Kelce recorded a season-high seven receptions for 89 yards. During the game, Kelce became the [[List of Kansas City Chiefs team records|Chiefs' leader in career receptions]], surpassing [[Tony Gonzalez]]'s previous record of 916 catches.<ref name="rally2024">{{cite web|url=https://www.espn.com/nfl/recap/_/gameId/401671674|title=Patrick Mahomes and Travis Kelce help Chiefs rally for 17-10 win over Chargers|publisher=Associated Press|website=ESPN.com|date=September 29, 2024|access-date=September 29, 2024|language=en}}</ref> On December 8, Kelce achieved his 12,000th career receiving yard in a 19–17 win over the [[Los Angeles Chargers]]. He became the fastest tight end in NFL history to achieve this, doing so in 172 games.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://clutchpoints.com/chiefs-news-travis-kelce-nfl-history-week-14-escape-chargers|title=Chiefs' Travis Kelce makes NFL history during Week 14 escape vs. Chargers|website=ClutchPoints|last=Villas|first=Rexwell|date=December 8, 2024|access-date=December 10, 2024}}</ref>

== Other ventures ==
===Philanthropy ===
[[File:Travis Kelce charity 2021.jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|Kelce, participating in a celebrity softball game at Eastlake's Classic Park to benefit the Lake Health Foundation]]
Noted for being generous with his time and resources, Kelce has received several awards for his philanthropic efforts. He received the Chiefs' [[Ed Block Courage Award]] in 2014. In 2020, the Chiefs nominated him for the [[Walter Payton Man of the Year Award]].<ref name="motyaward">{{Cite web |date=December 10, 2020 |title=Tight End Travis Kelce Named Chiefs Nominee for Walter Payton NFL Man of the Year Award Presented by Nationwide |url=https://www.chiefs.com/news/tight-end-travis-kelce-named-chiefs-nominee-for-walter-payton-nfl-man-of-the-yea |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231003014111/https://www.chiefs.com/news/tight-end-travis-kelce-named-chiefs-nominee-for-walter-payton-nfl-man-of-the-yea |archive-date=October 3, 2023 |access-date=January 27, 2024 |website=Chiefs.com}}</ref> That same year, fans voted him the winner of the NFL's Charity Challenge Award.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Brisco |first=Joshua |date=January 18, 2021 |title=Travis Kelce Wins NFL's Charity Challenge With #WPMOYChallenge Fan Vote |url=https://www.si.com/nfl/chiefs/news/travis-kelce-wins-nfl-charity-challenge-with-wpmoychallenge-fan-vote |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240109154436/https://www.si.com/nfl/chiefs/news/travis-kelce-wins-nfl-charity-challenge-wi |archive-date=January 9, 2024 |access-date=January 27, 2024 |magazine=[[Sports Illustrated]]}}</ref>

In 2015, Kelce created a foundation called Eighty-Seven & Running in his hometown of Cleveland, Ohio, with the goal of "empowering underprivileged youth".<ref name="motyaward" /><ref>{{Cite web |last=Kerr |first=Jeff |date=October 27, 2021 |title=How Travis Kelce has used his record-setting play at tight end to raise money for underprivileged youth |url=https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/how-travis-kelce-has-used-his-record-setting-play-at-tight-end-to-raise-money-for-underprivileged-youth/ |url-status=live |archive-date=February 3, 2022 |access-date=February 3, 2022 |website=CBSSports.com |language=en}}</ref><ref name="87andrunning">{{Cite magazine |last=Brisco |first=Joshua |date=May 25, 2021 |title=Travis Kelce Announces 'Ignition Lab' for Underserved Teens in Kansas City |url=https://www.si.com/nfl/chiefs/news/travis-kelce-announces-ignition-lab-for-underserved-teens-in-kansas-city |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240109120843/https://www.si.com/nfl/chiefs/news/travis-kelce-announces-ignition-lab-for-underserved-teens-in-kansas-city === Activism ===
Kelce has been a vocal advocate for [[social justice]]. In 2017, he became one of the highest-profile white NFL players to kneel during the [[The Star-Spangled Banner|national anthem]] in protest against police brutality, racism, and social inequalities in America.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Kay |first=Stanley |date=August 22, 2017 |title=Every NFL Player Who Has Protested During the National Anthem This Season |url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2017/08/22/national-anthem-protests-list-players-kneel |access-date=January 27, 2024 |magazine=Sports Illustrated |archive-date=January 9, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240109132445/https://www.si.com/nfl/2017/08/22/national-anthem-protests-list-players-kneel |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="BLM">{{Cite magazine |last=Klee |first=Miles |date=September 26, 2023 |title=Everything Swifties Need to Know About Travis Kelce |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/culture-sports/taylor-swift-travis-kelce-facts-swifties-kansas-city-chiefs-nfl-tight-end-1234831022/ |access-date=January 27, 2024 |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |archive-date=January 9, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240109133606/https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/culture-sports/taylor-swift-travis-kelce-facts-swifties-kansas-city-chiefs-nfl-tight-end-1234831022/ |url-status=live }}</ref> After the [[shooting of Jacob Blake]] by police officer Rusten Sheskey, Kelce, along with teammate Patrick Mahomes, spoke publicly in support of social justice.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hahn |first=Jason |date=August 28, 2020 |title=Super Bowl Champs Patrick Mahomes and Travis Kelce Speak Out amid Protests: 'We Need to Stand Up' |url=https://people.com/sports/super-bowl-champs-patrick-mahomes-travis-kelce-speak-out-amid-protests/ |access-date=January 27, 2024 |website=People.com |archive-date=January 27, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240127182437/https://people.com/sports/super-bowl-champs-patrick-mahomes-travis-kelce-speak-out-amid-protests/ |url-status=live }}</ref> He has pledged support for the [[Black Lives Matter]] movement<ref name="BLM" /> including in Kansas City.<ref>{{Cite web |date=February 4, 2021 |title=Chiefs' TE Travis Kelce on continuing to support Black Lives Matter in KC |url=https://www.kansascity.com/sports/nfl/kansas-city-chiefs/article249018010.html |access-date=January 27, 2024 |website=KansasCity.com |archive-date=February 6, 2021 joined students in virtual class discussions around the U.S. to discuss ''Black Boys,'' a [[Malcolm Jenkins]]-produced documentary that examines social and emotional effects of racism against Black men.<ref>{{Cite web |date=December 26, 2019 |title=Chiefs star tight end Travis Kelce encouraging people to talk openly about stopping racism |url-status=live }}</ref>

Kelce has also shown support to the [[LGBT]] community.<ref name="LGBT">{{Cite web |last=Casey |first=John |date=September 27, 2023 |title=Travis Kelce Will Have No Problem |url=https://www.advocate.com/voices/travis-kelce-taylor-swift-gaylor |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240123062230/https://www.advocate.com/voices/travis-kelce-taylor-swift-gaylor |archive-date=January 23, 2024 |access-date=June 17, 2024 |website=[[The Advocate (magazine)|The Advocate]]}}</ref> In 2021, he called for more acceptance of [[homosexuality in American football]], saying, "Anybody in this world [can play]."<ref name="LGBT" />

Vance]], and [[Lesley Manville]].<ref name="KJ24">{{Cite magazine |last=Madarang |first=Charisma |date=May 19, 2024 |title=Travis Kelce Declares 'The Tortured Poets Department' Favorite Album of the Year |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/travis-kelce-tortured-poets-department-favorite-album-kelce-jam-1235023623/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240519131115/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/travis-kelce-tortured-poets-department-favorite-album-kelce-jam-1235023623/ |archive-date=May 19, 2024 |access-date=May 19, 2024 |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]}}</ref>

Through his Super Bowl runs with the Chiefs, Kelce became known for reciting the chorus from the [[Beastie Boys]]' 1986 song "[[(You Gotta) Fight for Your Right (To Party!)]]" during team celebrations, first after the [[2019–20 NFL playoffs#AFC: Kansas City Chiefs 35, Tennessee Titans 24|2019 AFC Championship Game]] then again at the parade in Kansas City after clinching Super Bowl LIV. The Chiefs responded by making "Fight for Your Right" its touchdown song during games at [[Arrowhead Stadium]].<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Shapiro |first=Michael |date=January 19, 2020 |title=Chiefs TE Travis Kelce Channels Beastie Boys in AFC Championship Celebration |url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2020/01/20/travis-kelce-channels-beastie-boys-after-afc-championship |magazine=[[Sports Illustrated]] |access-date=February 20, 2023 |archive-date=February 17, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230217190218/https://www.si.com/nfl/2020/01/20/travis-kelce-channels-beastie-boys-after-afc-championship |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Goldman |first=Charles |date=May 15, 2020 |title=Reminder: Chiefs have a new touchdown song coming for 2020 |url=https://chiefswire.usatoday.com/2020/05/15/kansas-city-chiefs-touchdown-song-you-gotta-fight-for-your-right-to-party-beastie-boys/ |access-date=February 20, 2023 |website=Chiefs Wire |publisher=[[USA Today]] |archive-date=January 22, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210122233449/https://chiefswire.usatoday.com/2020/05/15/kansas-city-chiefs-touchdown-song-you-gotta-fight-for-your-right-to-party-beastie-boys/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In 2023, Kelce performed the song with [[Jimmy Fallon]] on ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon|The Tonight Show]]''.<ref>{{cite news |date=February 17, 2023 |title=Travis Kelce: Epic Karaoke sesh w/ Fallon |newspaper=[[TMZ]] |url=https://www.tmz.com/2023/02/17/travis-kelce-belts-out-fight-for-your-right-with-jimmy-fallon-in-epic-karaoke-sesh/ |access-date=February 20, 2023 |archive-date=February 22, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230222001752/https://www.tmz.com/2023/02/17/travis-kelce-belts-out-fight-for-your-right-with-jimmy-fallon-in-epic-karaoke-sesh/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

Kelce was featured, with his brother Jason, on the cover of "[[Fairytale of New York]]" (1987) by [[the Pogues]] featuring [[Kirsty MacColl]], titled "Fairytale of Philadelphia", which appeared on the 2023 album ''[[A Philly Special Christmas Special]]'';<ref>{{cite news |last=DeLuca |first=Dan |date=November 14, 2023 |title=Every new song from the Eagles' 'A Philly Special Christmas Special' reviewed. As they're released. |newspaper=The Philadelphia Inquirer |url=https://www.inquirer.com/entertainment/music/eagles-christmas-album-2023-reviews-20231102.html |access-date=November 18, 2023 |archive-date=November 17, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231117230543/https://www.inquirer.com/entertainment/music/eagles-christmas-album-2023-reviews-20231102.html |url-status=live }}</ref> proceeds from the album benefit various charity institutions in Philadelphia. "Fairytale of Philadelphia" topped the US [[iTunes]] chart, following which the brothers thanked the [[Swifties]].<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Dailey |first=Hannah |date=November 22, 2023 |title=Jason and Travis Kelce Thank Taylor Swift & Swifties For Sending Christmas Single to No. 1 on iTunes |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/jason-travis-kelce-thank-swifties-christmas-single-1235508149/ |access-date=November 22, 2023 |magazine=Billboard |archive-date=November 22, 2023 further debuted at number five on the [[Digital Songs|''Billboard'' Digital Song Sales]] chart and number two on ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Rock Digital Song Sales with 6,000 downloads sold in the first week.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Zellner |first=Xander |date=November 21, 2023 |title=10 First-Timers on Billboard's Charts This Week: Travis Kelce, Jason Kelce, The Red Clay Strays & |url-status=live }}</ref> The song climbed to number one on both charts on its second week of release, making the brothers ''Billboard''-charting artists.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Rutherford In April 2023, Kelce announced the launch of his own annual [[music festival]] called Kelce Jam.<ref name="kelcejam">{{Cite news |last=Fekadu |first=Mesfin |date=April 4, 2023 |title=Super Bowl Champion Travis Kelce to Launch His Own Music Festival Called Kelce Jam (Exclusive) |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/music-news/travis-kelce-launch-music-festival-kelce-jam-1235366573/ |access-date=January 9, 2024 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |archive-date=January 9, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240109122512/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/music-news/travis-kelce-launch-music-festival-kelce-jam-1235366573/ |url-status=live }}</ref> The first edition of the event, held in [[Bonner Springs, Kansas]] during the [[2023 NFL draft]] weekend, featured artists including [[Machine Gun Kelly (musician)|Machine Gun Kelly]], [[Rick Ross]], [[Loud Luxury]] and [[Tech N9ne]].<ref name="kelcejam" /> The festival sold its first 10,000 tickets in 20 minutes, and was eventually sold out with 18,000 people in attendance.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Fedotin |first=Jeff |date=May 2, 2023 |title=Kansas City Chiefs All-Pro Travis Kelce Has Launched His Own Clothing Line |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jefffedotin/2021/12/13/kansas-city-chiefs-all-pro-travis-kelce-has-launched-his-own-clothing-line/ |access-date=January 27, 2024 |website=Forbes |language=en |archive-date=January 27, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240127182138/https://www.forbes.com/sites/jefffedotin/2021/12/13/kansas-city-chiefs-all-pro-travis-kelce-has-launched-his-own-clothing-line/ |url-status=live }}</ref> The second edition of the festival in 2024, saw an attendance of 20,000 fans with headlining performances from [[2 Chainz]], [[Diplo]] and [[Lil Wayne]].<ref name="KJ24" />

===''New Heights''  podcast (Since 2022) ===

In September 2022, Kelce and his brother Jason launched a weekly [[sports podcast]] called ''[[New Heights|New Heights with Jason & Travis Kelce]],'' produced with Wave Sports + Entertainment.<ref
